title: 03. What are little big histories?
description: Video about the question 'What are little big histories?' By creating a little big history you can explore big history in a structured an systematic way. Link big history to something close to you and make distant events and processes come to life. The concept of little big history makes it easy to come up with your own new ideas.

title: 02. How big is big history?
description:
Video about the question 'How big is big history?' How can you place human history in a perspective of time and distance? Only recently we know how old the universe is. When you compress the age of the universe in one year, you could say that around Christmas the dinosaurs would appear. And by December 30, they would be wiped out.So the last 2 days of the year would see the evolution of mammals as we know them and human beings only appear in the last 6 minutes of that year. 
If you compare our sun with a grapefruit the earth can be seen as a peppercorn on 10 metres distance.

title: 01. How can we summarize 13.8 billion years in one brief course?
description: Video about the question: how can we summarize 13.8 billion years in one brief course? Obviously, you have to leave things out. How do you determine what to address and what not? You are invited to develop your own personal answer to this question.

title: 1. A first exploration of big history
description: Big history is a big subject. What do you address and what do you leave out? What is big history about and how can you use little big histories to explore further?

title: 04. Can big history reunify all our knowledge?
description: Video about the question 'Can big history reunify all our knowledge?' What to leave out and what not? We can make these decisions based on theories: mental constructs that can help us order reality. What is required for the development of complexity? You need energy flows through matter and you need very good circumstances. This theory is underlying all of natural science. But how can we connect all theories, including history, psychology etc. There is a major challenge here.

title: 04. Can big history reunify all our knowledge?
description: Video about the question 'Can big history reunify all our knowledge?' What to leave out and what not? We can make these decisions based on theories: mental constructs that can help us order reality. What is required for the development of complexity? You need energy flows through matter and you need very good circumstances. This theory is underlying all of natural science. But how can we connect all theories, including history, psychology etc. There is a major challenge here.

title: Exercises 5
Using a Vortex | Wageningen UR
description: Instruction on how to use a Vortex mixer

Didactiek van macro-meso-micro denken bij scheikunde

      Inleiding
Beste docent of docent-in-opleiding scheikunde,


Dit arrangement bevat opdrachten op het gebied van de didactiek van macro-meso-micro-denken, een belangrijk nieuw onderwerp in de scheikunde in het voortgezet onderwijs.


Het is bedoeld voor zelfstudie of kan worden ingepast in het programma van de lerarenopleiding. De opdrachten bouwen op elkaar voort.


Het materiaal is ontwikkeld in het kader van het project online-bètadidactiek en kan vrij gebruikt worden voor opleidingsdoeleinden.


In de onderstaande video wordt aangegeven wat het onderwerp macro-meso-micro inhoudt en waarom het van belang is in het voortgezet onderwijs:


https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B27or32IlB2bRTJXUERzbllxTmc/view?usp=sharing


 


Dit arrangement heeft drie onderdelen

1. Studieopdracht gericht op conceptuele analyse

2. Onderzoeksopdracht gericht op leerlingdenkbeelden

3. Ontwerpopdracht gericht op instructiemateriaal




Dit komt overeen met de hoekpunten van de zogenaamde vakdidactische driehoek: 



                                    Vakdidactische driehoek


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


De opdrachten kosten circa 30 uur werk. Het is aan te raden een selectie te maken.


 


Veel studieplezier,


Ruud Kok, lerarenopleider scheikunde, Hogeschool van Amsterdam


​Hans Poorthuis, lerarenopleider natuurkunde Hogeschool Utrecht


Astrid Bulte, vakdidacticus scheikunde Universiteit Utrecht

        maakt en deelt.

                Hans Poorthuis

files.title: Didactiek van macro-meso-micro denken bij scheikunde.pdf

title: Didactiek van macro-meso-micro denken bij scheikunde
Les 12 - Audio en MIDI 1
description:
Als we op een computer met muziek werken, komen we in aanraking met Audio, MIDI of een combinatie van beide. In deze les ligt de nadruk op MIDI. 

Aan de orde komen:
Wat is het en wat kun je ermee? 
Hoe kun je binnen Sibelius software gebruik maken van MIDI (play, record, mixer, sounds, export audio) 
Het verschijnsel Latency

title: 4. Macro: Economic Performance & Employment
description: Learn about some basic theories of Macroeconomics.  We focus on how you can use these theories in daily business operation and understand the business world better.

text:
Economics – Changes on the labour market 
International Business School 
Hanze University of Applied Sciences, The Netherlands 



Learning objective 

Explain the effect of changes in the labour market on 
the real wage rate and quantity of labour in hours. 

2 15/5/15 



Labour market 

Supply for labour represents workers’ willingness to work at a given 
(real) wage rate. Any factor influencing the willingness of workers, 
except a change in wages, will lead to a shift of the labour supply 
curve. 
 
Possible factors: 

•  level of social benefits 
•  migration 
•  opportunity cost of leisure time  

 - diagram outside scope course 

3 15/5/15 



Effect on diagram 

real
 wages  
 

quantity of labour in hours 

labour market 

SL 

DL 

Assume	  government
	  reduces	  welfare	  benefits	  

⇒ more	  incen6ve	  
	  	  	  	  	  to	  work	   ⇒ SL	  shi;s	  to	  right	  Wages

	  falls	  



Labour market 

Demand for labour represents employers / firms willingness to 
employ workers at a given (real) wage rate. Any factor influencing 
the willingness of employers to employ workers, except a change in 
wages, will lead to a shift of the labour demand curve. 
 
Possible factors: 

•  demand for a product  
•  productivity of labour 
•  price and productivity of machinery and technology (substitution) 

5 15/5/15 



Wages
	  increase

 coming part.
